comment: I'm fan enough of the physicist Richard Feynman to know that one of the few things that blew his mind was the genius of chemists (he was impressed by how they were able to deduce complicated chemical structures by inference from indirect observation "and lo and behold, the chemists are almost always right!"). This course is a great example of why that should be true.
Excellent lecture! Your ability to simplify complex concepts is remarkable.

Emmanuel Kant said we could never know the “ thing in itself “ . We bring our faculties to the thing in itself, and experience the resulting phenomenon. This is an attempt to know the “thing in itself “, and we cannot know something without it being affected by ourselves. So as we approach knowledge of the “thing in itself” the more it seems to lack sense to us. Therefore maybe it is true that no one really understands this stuff, or every will.

@kenichikenuzo7352  This is not the same thing at all... What you are learning are the basics which is taught in any general chemistry or honors chemistry course in high school. This is physical chemistry or specifically the quantum chemistry introduction. The work the students have to do involves solving the Schrodinger equation and computing expectation values/uncertainties of measurements. The requirements to take this class vary from university to university but the requirements are generally calculus II or calculus III. However, to really interpret and understand results it is generally recommended to have linear algebra and ordinary differential equations taken. Even that may not be enough math to really get into the complexities that come from these equations.   http://pollux.chem.umn.edu/4502/3502_HWkey4.pdf  This is likely closer to the type of problems they would be asked to solve on homework sets and exams. I looked at chapter 2 and I can assure you that the material you are working through is not the same as this course. This course is generally considered the hardest for anyone pursuing a bachelors in chemistry.

I've seen physicists claim that an electron can be everywhere at the same time until it's measured, and that's when you find where it's at, or where it decided to be due to the act of measuring.   But if there are nodes in the wave function that contain no probability of the electron being there, then what many physicists say about the electron being "everywhere" at once, well it's not true, at least in the one electron hydrogen atom orbitals this wonderful professor talks about.  Am I missing something here, enlightenment is welcome! Thanks

It's a bit a semantics to say everywhere at once. The quantum numbers give you discrete values for the allowable  ENERGY levels of the wave function they're called eigenvalues of applying the Hamiltonian operator to the wave function. But the wave function ψ itself is a defferential equation that gives a probably distribution of finding a particle at a particular point. The constraint on the solutions is that at positive and negative infinity ψ must be equal to 0 bht other than that it is typically a continuous function

I think you heard it from someone who tried to show you quantum weirdness. Physicists words goes like this: Say the electron can be at only two position 1 and 2. Until it is observed it is not at 1, also not in at 2, it is also not at 1 and 2 at the same time, also it is not that it is nowhere. The problem lies that we are using daily language to describe a world we never known. So, Physicists gave it a new name. They say it is in a superposition of being at |1> and |2>. Written as |1>+|2>. In case of hydrogen atom the electron is in a superposition of continous wavefunctions. Each normalized coeficients(calculated using Fourier analysis) determine the probability of finding electron in that state. When you measure the state(like during photoelectric effect) electron is bound to take only one state.

The wave function has no physical meaning, but the square of the wave function time a volume element is the probability of finding the electron in this volume element. Ant the orbital is a threshold of volume, where the probability of finding an electron in it is > 90 % or something
